questions.question: Traits of Assertive Communicators?

choices.answer: Clearly states needs and wants
Assumes caregiver knows what they need
Mumbles their needs
Does not speak up for what they need or want

questions.question: Traits of Assertive Communicators?

choices.answer: Eye contact
Interrupts when you disagree or don't like what's being said
Listens to others without interrupting
Roll your eyes let them know you disagree with them

questions.question: Traits of Assertive Communicators?

choices.answer: Appropriate speaking volume
Interrupt because what you say is more important
Steady tone of voice
Raise your voice to be higher than other person's voice

questions.question: Traits of Assertive Communicators?

choices.answer: Confident body language
Stare at your phone
Turn your back to ignore them
Put your head in your arms to ignore what's being said

questions.question: How to say "no" when you need to say it

choices.answer: Say it clearly, without lying about the reasons.
Say it like, "no!" and make up an excuse
Offer to help find another solution.
Use a short-tempered and snappy response to get it over

questions.question: How to calmly express your thoughts and feelings

choices.answer: Give the silent treatment to let them know you're annoyed
Shame the other person to make yourself feel better
Yell or use threats to make them take you seriously
Use "I statements" and take responsibility for your emotions

questions.question: How to calmly express your thoughts and feelings

choices.answer: Answer in a calm and factual manner. "I feel.."
Lie how you feel and just postpone telling the truth
Scream how you feel then walk away
Make up an answer that you think they want to hear

questions.question: How to plan what you need to say

choices.answer: Know your needs and wants and how to express them.
Come up with specific words or sentences you can use
Practice by yourself how to calmly express your fears
Come up with an answer on the spot

questions.question: How to express negative thoughts and feelings in a healthy and positive manner

choices.answer: Allow yourself to be angry, but always be respectful.
Tell the truth, no matter if it's mean and hurtful
Be honest, but also protect other person's feelings.
It doesn't matter if you hurt someone's feelings

questions.question: How to validate someone's feelings.

choices.answer: "I understand you're confused, how can I help clarify?"
"Just get over it, you can't fix it anyways."
"It seems you're feeling upset, that must be frustrating."
"It's not a big deal, I don't know why you're so upset."

questions.question: Assertiveness versus Aggression. Which two are assertive?

choices.answer: Considering the rights, needs, and wants of others
Doing what's in your best interest without care for others
You take what you want regardless, and you don't usually ask
being honest and using precise language to avoid confusion

questions.question: Is being assertive is the easier route?

choices.answer: True
False

questions.question: Assertiveness is a skill that can be learned and needs to be regularly practiced.

choices.answer: True
False

questions.question: Being assertive start with....

choices.answer: Assuming people know your thoughts
A good understanding of who you are
Expecting others to know how you feel

questions.question: Being assertive starts with...

choices.answer: A belief in the value you bring and hold inside of you
Thinking no one will listen to you anways
A belief that it's too hard to learn to be assertive
Wanting someone else to speak up for you.

questions.question: Assertiveness helps build what...

choices.answer: Self-confidence
Inward shame
a belief you're more important than others
It's stupid, it doesn't build anything

questions.question: Being assertive can help you how?

choices.answer: See the value in your friend and in his/her position
Allow you to win more discussions and arguments
Find common ground more easily with your friend
It can't help me.

questions.question: Being assertive can help you how?

choices.answer: Learn to be better at decision making
Learn to manipulate other people to do what I ask
Make me the boss

questions.question: Being assertive can help you how?

choices.answer: Feel less stressed about decisions or my thoughts/feelings
Feel more confused about my options
Feel more frustrated when I can't fix the problem

questions.question: Being assertive can help you how?

choices.answer: Make decisions faster
Take more time to make decisions
Not care about my circumstances
